Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Diagnostic vs. Non-Diagnostic Facial Features in Eyewitness Identification

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The problem of innocent suspects being mistakenly convicted of a crime they did not commit and the parallel problem of guilty suspects being mistakenly released into society are attributable in no small part to the fallibility of eyewitness memory. A great deal of eyewitness memory research has focused on reducing false identifications of innocent suspects (thereby reducing the chances that they will be wrongly convicted). However, methods that reduce that unfortunate error often have the effect of increasing the complementary error, namely, the error of failing to identify guilty suspects. That tradeoff might be considered acceptable, but a better approach would involve reducing both errors simultaneously. To date, very little research has been conducted with that goal in mind, but it is the goal of the research proposed here. In particular, this research asks what can be done to enhance eyewitness discriminability (i.e., the ability to tell the difference between innocent and guilty suspects). To answer this question, the research is guided by a new theory of eyewitness identification: the diagnostic feature-detection hypothesis. Enhancing the discriminability of eyewitness memory procedures has significant broader impacts because it would decrease misidentifications of the innocent while at the same time increasing identifications of the guilty.

This project will focus on three widely used eyewitness identification procedures: the traditional simultaneous lineup (in which 6 faces are shown to the witness simultaneously), the newer sequential lineup (in which the 6 faces are shown to the witness one at a time), and the showup procedure (in which only one face is shown to a witness for a yes/no decision). Virtually all police departments make use of the showup procedure (because it is often the only possibility in a fast-moving investigation), and nearly 30% of police departments have switched from the simultaneous lineup procedure to the sequential procedure. However, contrary to what was previously believed, recent work has found that both the showup and the sequential lineup are inferior to the simultaneous procedure (i.e., the simultaneous procedure can reduce false identifications of innocent suspects while at the same time increasing correct identifications of guilty suspects compared to the other two procedure). Given the common and likely continued use of the showup procedure and sequential lineup, this research proposes a series of experiments to investigate simple and convenient ways to enhance the diagnostic accuracy of these eyewitness identification procedures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the domain of eyewitness memory, a great deal of work has focused on reducing false identifications of innocent suspects. However, methods that reduce that unfortunate error often have the effect of increasing the complementary error, namely, the error of failing to identify guilty suspects. That tradeoff might be considered acceptable, but a better approach would involve reducing both errors simultaneously. The only way to accomplish that goal would be to enhance the ability of an eyewitness to distinguish between innocent and guilty suspects in a lineup (i.e., to enhance discriminability). This research was conducted with that goal in mind. In the field of diagnostic medicine, the analogous goal is always to minimize false positives (i.e., the false detection of a disease) while simultaneously maximizing true positives (i.e., the correct detection of a disease). The only way to accomplish both goals at the same time is to maximize discriminability, which means the first step is to find a way to measure discriminability. In the field of diagnostic medicine, it has been understood for decades that the appropriate way to measure discriminability without relying on detailed theoretical assumptions is to analyze the receiver operating characteristic (ROC). ROC analysis was only recently introduced to the field of eyewitness memory (Mickes et al, 2012), and the first such analyses suggest that simultaneous lineups yield higher discriminability than both showups and sequential lineups as well. Because both procedures (showups and sequential lineups) will continue to be used by the police, this research investigated (1) whether methods could be found that will enhance discriminability for both procedures and (2) whether ROC analysis (a still somewhat controversial methodology in eyewitness identification) is the appropriate way to measure discriminability.

 

Intellectual Merit: Our findings indicated that ROC analysis is in fact well suited to measuring discriminability for different eyewitness identification procedures. In addition, we found that discriminability for showups can be increased by surrounding a suspect’s face with the faces of fillers who match the suspect’s description. It was still a showup (i.e., the participant-witness was asked whether or not the suspect was the person they saw commit the simulated crime), but surrounding that suspect’s face with other similar faces enhanced discriminability as measured by ROC analysis. Enhancing discriminability for sequential lineups proved to be more difficult because, contrary to what we assumed, the sequential procedure exhibits strong position effects. In other words, empirical discriminability is much lower when the suspect appears late in the lineup compared to when the suspect appears early in the lineup. Thus, to date, it has proven to be difficult to find a way to make sequential lineups competitive with simultaneous lineups. Our results do show that eliminating the stopping rule in the sequential procedure (i.e., by counting the most confident ID, not the first ID) might serve to minimize the difference in discriminability between simultaneous and sequential lineups.

 

Broader Impacts: The problem of innocent suspects being mistakenly convicted of a crime they did not commit and the parallel problem of guilty suspects being mistakenly released into society are attributable in no small part to the fallibility of eyewitness memory. Moreover, addressing one problem without exacerbating the other is exceptionally difficult to do, but it is precisely the focus of this research. Finding a way to enhance discriminability is tantamount to finding a way to address both problems at the same time. Helping to reduce the corrosive effects on the legal system associated with convicting the innocent while at the same time helping to protect society from dangerous criminals who might otherwise go free are the potential broader impacts of the research we conducted.
